Award.AwardTitle: Experimental and theoretical trait-based approaches to optimizing algal biofuel polycultures

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Litchman
Proposal Number: 1134215

Intellectual Merit

Microalgae are a promising renewable feedstock for sustainable biofuel production, and offer several unique advantages for this purpose, including high growth rate and photosynthetic efficiency, use of marginal land for lipid-rich biomass production, potential use of wastewater as a nutrient source, and relatively low energy requirements for converting its biomass (lipids) into biofuel (biodiesel). Approaches to intensification of algal biofuel production typically focus on identifying and growing monocultures of microalgal species shown to produce high amounts of lipids. However, these monocultures, because of inherent physiological trade-offs, may not utilize nutrients and light for maximum efficiency, are susceptible to invasions by other species, and can exhibit fluctuations in biomass and lipid productivity. In contrast, microalgal polycultures can potentially circumvent these eco-physiological tradeoffs and provide a more robust platform for algal biofuels production, particularly in scalable open cultivation systems.

The overall goal of the proposed research is to design multispecies microalgal communities that optimize resource utilization, biomass production, and lipid accumulation under changing environmental conditions while providing increased resistance to pathogens and invasions by nuisance species. Towards this end, the diverse eco-physiological traits of many algal species will be analyzed to deduce the trade-offs among these traits, and from this analysis, the appropriate species for microalgal consortia will be identified that maximize multiple goal functions under process constraints. Mathematical models, combined with laboratory experiments for parameter estimation and model validation, will be used to assess the dynamic behavior of the designed polyculture communities, and identify those with best performance characteristics relative to their respective monocultures. The most promising microalgal communities will be further investigated for scalability using enclosed photobioreactors and open pond cultivation systems.

Broader Impacts

The proposed education and outreach activities will offer K-12 student and teacher experiences in bioenergy topics through the Kellogg Biological Station (KBS) GK-12 Bioenergy Sustainability Project, which engages local rural schools in ecological and sustainability research. The PI will host a high school teacher during the summer to develop age-appropriate, hands-on educational modules on bionergy, sustainability, and aquatic ecology. A postdoctoral associate will be trained in interdisciplinary research combining mathematical modeling, ecological principles, and bioenergy applications, and will interact with the researchers from the Great Lakes Bioenergy Research Center (GLBRC) to exchange ideas on the use of polycultures for biofuel production.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cultivating microalgae for lipid production that can be transformed into fuel may help solve the problem of renewable biofuels.  In this project, we explored how using ecological principles can increase the productivity of algal biofuels. Growing different algal species with complementary characteristics may help increase the efficiency of their use of available resources and, thus, increase their biomass and lipid production. Using laboratory experiments with diverse species of microalgae, we showed that under variable environmental conditions, growing multiple species together led to a more stable biomass than growing a single species. Furthermore, growing species from two different taxonomic groups (green algae and cyanobacteria) led to higher lipid yields that were predicted based on the growth of species in monocultures. Moreover, including species that can assimilate nitrogen from the atmosphere (some species of cyanobacteria) yielded more lipid production under nitrogen-limited conditions.   

We also showed that the concentrations of different fatty acids were different in major groups of microalgae, such as green algae, diatoms, cyanobacteria and cryptophytes. The fatty acid composition also depended on temperature. This has important implications for growing microalgae outdoors under varying temperatures. We found that some algae, such as diatoms, had a more optimal composition of fatty acids with respect to their suitability for biodiesel production.

We explored the possibility of growing microalgae for biofuel production in brewery wastewater and found that some species of microalgae were capable of producing high biomass and lipid content, while taking up high concentrations of nutrients from the wastewater. This opens up the possibility of increasing the sustainability of algal biofuel production and, at the same time, allows for efficient brewery wastewater remediation.  We also found that some high lipid-producing algae that were not able to grow in undiluted brewery wastewater could grow in the water that was diluted slightly. We also found that a two-stage approach where wastewater-tolerant algae were grown first and then that water was used to grow more sensitive algae for a more efficient nutrient removal and remediation.

The project trained two graduate students, several undergraduate students and one postdoctoral researcher. The students and the postdoc learned new algal cultivation techniques, various laboratory methods, such as nutrient and lipid measurements, statistical analyses and manuscript writing. Among other educational activities, K-12 students and teachers from rural school districts learned about the broad goals of the project, key results and the general information about environmental change, algal biofuels and sustainability.
